verses.text: When Isaac was old and his eyes were so dim that he could not see, he called Esau his elder son and said to him, 'My son.' And he answered, 'Here I am.'
verses.comment: Isaac's failing eyesight foreshadows the handing on of the blessing—note also future instances of patriarchs blessing their sons when near death (Genesis 48).

verses.text: He said, 'See, I am old; I do not know the day of my death.'
verses.comment: Isaac acknowledges the uncertainty of life, echoing the wisdom later found in James 4:14 about life's brevity.

verses.text: 'Now then, take your weapons, your quiver and your bow, and go out to the open country and hunt game for me.'
verses.comment: Esau is the skilled hunter, as previously described. Isaac's preference for Esau is partly due to this skill.

verses.text: 'Prepare me a tasty dish, such as I love, and bring it to me that I may eat, so that my soul may bless you before I die.'
verses.comment: The blessing here is not simply a wish, but carries the power and permanence rooted in divine promise. The concept of blessing is foundational in salvation history.

verses.text: Now Rebekah was listening when Isaac spoke to his son Esau. So when Esau went to the field to hunt game and bring it,
verses.comment: Rebekah's attention to Isaac's words shows her active participation in God's plan, relating to her earlier revelation in Gen. 25:23.

verses.text: Rebekah said to her son Jacob, 'I heard your father speak to your brother Esau,'
verses.comment: Jacob is addressed as 'her son,' indicating favoritism. Note how God uses even human favoritism for His providence.

verses.text: 'Bring me game and prepare for me a tasty dish, that I may eat it and bless you in the presence of the LORD before my death.'
verses.comment: Rebekah quotes Isaac's intention about the blessing. The phrase 'in the presence of the LORD' shows consciousness of God's oversight of the blessing.

verses.text: 'Now therefore, my son, obey my voice as I command you.'
verses.comment: Obedience to parental instruction is a recurring biblical theme (Exod. 20:12, Eph. 6:1). Jacob's obedience leads to the ancestral blessing.

verses.text: 'Go now to the flock and bring me two good young goats, that I may prepare them as a tasty dish for your father, such as he loves.'
verses.comment: The use of goats instead of wild game demonstrates resourcefulness. The meal's preparation also alludes to ritual meals that accompany blessings or covenants.

verses.text: 'You shall bring it to your father, that he may eat, so that he may bless you before his death.'
verses.comment: Jacob is to present himself as Esau. The blessing, once given, is irrevocable, showing the solemnity of such words (Hebrews 11:20).

verses.text: And Jacob said to his mother Rebekah, 'Behold, my brother Esau is a hairy man, and I am a smooth man.'
verses.comment: Jacob notes their physical differences. The contrast between Jacob and Esau is foundational to later distinctions between their descendants (Mal. 1:2-3; Rom 9:10-13).

verses.text: 'What if my father touches me? I will seem to be mocking him and bring a curse on myself and not a blessing.'
verses.comment: The fear of a curse shows the seriousness of blessings and curses in the ancient world, as reflected later in the Mosaic Law.

verses.text: But his mother said to him, 'Let your curse be on me, my son; only obey my voice, and go, bring them to me.'
verses.comment: Rebekah takes responsibility for the risk, mirroring the role of one who bears burdens for another. This prefigures the idea of substitution found later in Scripture.

verses.text: So he went and took them and brought them to his mother, and his mother prepared a tasty dish, just as his father loved.
verses.comment: The repeated emphasis on obedience connects to the importance of right action in faith tradition (James 2:21-24).

verses.text: Then Rebekah took the best garments of Esau, her elder son, which were with her in the house, and put them on Jacob, her younger son.
verses.comment: Garments are symbolic, later showing status and inheritance (the Father’s robe in Luke 15:22).

verses.text: She put the skins of the young goats on his hands and on the smooth part of his neck.
verses.comment: The physical disguise is essential for the deception; skins may also anticipate later sacrificial imagery.

verses.text: Then she gave the tasty dish and the bread, which she had prepared, into the hand of her son Jacob.
verses.comment: The giving of food before a blessing has echoes in later rituals, like the Passover and Eucharistic themes.

verses.text: So he went in to his father and said, 'My father.' And he said, 'Here I am. Who are you, my son?'
verses.comment: Isaac's question shows uncertainty. Identification is at the heart of the story.

verses.text: Jacob said to his father, 'I am Esau your firstborn; I have done as you told me. Now sit up and eat of my game, that your soul may bless me.'
verses.comment: Jacob's statement involves direct deception, yet fulfills the prophecy of Gen. 25:23 about the older serving the younger. God’s foreknowledge and human free will feature here.

verses.text: Isaac said to his son, 'How is it that you have found it so quickly, my son?' And he answered, 'Because the LORD your God brought it to me.'
verses.comment: Jacob invokes the LORD, furthering the deception, yet relating everything back to divine providence.

verses.text: Then Isaac said to Jacob, 'Come near, that I may feel you, my son, to know whether you are really my son Esau or not.'
verses.comment: Isaac seeks physical confirmation. The emphasis on senses points to human limitations when discerning divine choice.

verses.text: So Jacob went near to Isaac his father, who felt him and said, 'The voice is Jacob’s voice, but the hands are the hands of Esau.'
verses.comment: Isaac’s confusion between sense and identity points to the mystery of God’s choice, which does not always align with human expectation.

verses.text: He did not recognize him, because his hands were hairy like his brother Esau’s hands; so he blessed him.
verses.comment: Isaac proceeds with the blessing based on what his senses tell him, highlighting how the mystery of the blessing supersedes mere appearances.

verses.text: He said, 'Are you really my son Esau?' He answered, 'I am.'
verses.comment: Jacob’s second affirmation of identity solidifies the deception, but the blessing’s effect will extend beyond human intent.

verses.text: Then he said, 'Bring it near to me, so that I may eat of my son’s game and bless you.' So he brought it near to him, and he ate; and he brought him wine, and he drank.
verses.comment: Wine accompanying bread or food marks important covenant moments (see Melchizedek, Gen. 14:18, and Christ instituting the Eucharist in Matthew 26:26-29).

verses.text: His father Isaac said to him, 'Come near now and kiss me, my son.'
verses.comment: A kiss customarily accompanies blessings, signifying affection and the passing of authority (see 2 Samuel 15:5; Luke 15:20).

verses.text: So he came near and kissed him. Isaac smelled the scent of his garments, and blessed him, saying, 'See, the scent of my son is as the scent of a field that the LORD has blessed.'
verses.comment: The smell of the field recalls the earth’s blessing. Sensory elements heighten the dignity of the blessing.

verses.text: 'May God give you of the dew of heaven, and of the fatness of the earth, and plenty of grain and new wine.'
verses.comment: The blessing invokes abundance. 'Dew' and 'fatness' symbolize divine favor—see how these blessings foreshadow the Promised Land.

verses.text: 'Let peoples serve you, and nations bow down to you. Be lord over your brothers, and may your mother’s sons bow down to you. Cursed be everyone who curses you, and blessed be everyone who blesses you!'
verses.comment: The climax of the Abrahamic blessing: authority, protection, and reversal of roles, fulfilling God’s word in Gen. 25:23.

verses.text: As soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had scarcely gone out from his father Isaac’s presence, Esau his brother came in from his hunting.
verses.comment: The timing is precise—providential, underscoring the unrepeatable and irrevocable nature of the blessing.

verses.text: He also prepared a tasty dish and brought it to his father. He said to his father, 'Let my father arise, and eat of his son’s game, so that you may bless me.'
verses.comment: Esau confidently expects the birthright blessing, demonstrating his lack of awareness of Jacob’s earlier deception.

verses.text: His father Isaac said to him, 'Who are you?' He answered, 'I am your son, your firstborn, Esau.'
verses.comment: A painful revelation: this is the turning point for both Isaac and Esau, who now realize the blessing has been given away.

verses.text: Then Isaac trembled violently, and said, 'Who was it then that hunted game and brought it to me, and I ate it all before you came, and blessed him? Yes, and he shall be blessed.'
verses.comment: Isaac’s violent trembling shows his awareness of divine overruling. The blessing stands: it is a divinely sanctioned act.

verses.text: When Esau heard the words of his father, he cried out with an exceedingly great and bitter cry, and said to his father, 'Bless me, even me also, O my father!'
verses.comment: Esau’s response is deeply emotional, and highlights the irrevocability of spiritual realities—see Hebrews 12:16-17 for later New Testament reflection.

verses.text: But he said, 'Your brother came deceitfully, and has taken away your blessing.'
verses.comment: This recalls Esau’s previous loss of the birthright. The interplay of free will and providence invites deeper meditation on the means God uses to accomplish His purposes.

verses.text: Esau said, 'Is he not rightly named Jacob? For he has cheated me these two times. He took away my birthright, and now look, he has taken away my blessing.' Then he said, 'Have you not reserved a blessing for me?'
verses.comment: The meaning of 'Jacob' is 'supplanter.' Esau refers to the birthright episode; a further illustration of God’s mysterious election.

verses.text: Isaac answered Esau, 'Behold, I have made him lord over you, and all his brothers I have given to him as servants, and with grain and wine I have sustained him. What then can I do for you, my son?'
verses.comment: Isaac cannot reverse his blessing, indicating there is an order endowed with both divine and patriarchal authority.

verses.text: Esau said to his father, 'Have you but one blessing, my father? Bless me, even me also, O my father.' And Esau lifted up his voice and wept.
verses.comment: Esau’s anguish underlines the profound value communities place on patriarchal blessing. It also prefigures greater tears shed by those who miss out on spiritual inheritance (Luke 13:28).

verses.text: Then Isaac his father answered and said to him, 'Behold, away from the fatness of the earth shall your dwelling be, and away from the dew of heaven above.'
verses.comment: Esau’s 'blessing' is more prophecy than favor—exile and wandering contrasted with inheritance.

verses.text: 'By your sword you shall live, and you shall serve your brother; and it shall come to pass, when you break loose, that you shall break his yoke from your neck.'
verses.comment: A promise of struggle, service, and eventual deliverance. The history of Edom and Israel fulfills this prophecy in stages.

verses.text: Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing with which his father had blessed him. Esau said in his heart, 'The days of mourning for my father are near; then I will kill my brother Jacob.'
verses.comment: Esau’s internal resentment echoes Cain’s against Abel. The pattern of enmity among brothers runs throughout Scripture and is resolved redemptively in Christ (Eph. 2:14-16).

verses.text: These words of Esau her elder son were told to Rebekah. So she sent and called for Jacob her younger son, and said to him, 'Behold, your brother Esau is consoling himself about you by planning to kill you.'
verses.comment: Rebekah’s intervention again preserves the chosen line. God’s providence steers the outcome through human decisions and reactions.

verses.text: Now therefore, my son, obey my voice; arise, flee to Laban, my brother, in Haran,
verses.comment: Jacob’s flight out of necessity ultimately advances the fulfillment of God’s promise, paralleling Moses, David, and Christ in their times of exile.

verses.text: 'And stay with him a while, until your brother’s fury turns away.'
verses.comment: Rebekah anticipates reconciliation. Reunions after strife are a motif in Genesis (Joseph and his brothers: Gen. 45).

verses.text: 'Until your brother’s anger turns away from you, and he forgets what you have done to him. Then I will send and fetch you from there. Why should I be bereaved of you both in one day?'
verses.comment: Rebekah’s grief points to the cost of family division, a theme often explored in parables (cf. Luke 15:11-32).

verses.text: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, 'I am weary of my life because of the daughters of Heth. If Jacob takes a wife from the daughters of Heth, like these, from the daughters of the land, what good will my life be to me?'
verses.comment: The concern for a God-fearing spouse connects the patriarchal narrative to the call for spiritual unity in later generations (2 Cor. 6:14).
